author: @Hotdads1
text: I know I‚Äôm commenting on this a year later but you were wrong about the travel industry specifically regarding short term rentals like Airbnb and VRBO. What happened in regards to travel was people were flying less which means destination vacations like Hawaii or flying across the country were showing a major slow down. Instead, people started looking for great areas that they could drive to and at a reasonable distance. Drive to destinations like The Smoky Mountains in Tennessee, Destin Florida, and Miramar beach and Joshua Tree absolutely exploded. Owners of rentals were seeing the highest rates they‚Äôve ever been able to charge because people just wanted to get away and a lot of the travelers were using their COVID checks to pay for these vacations. That and the increase in remote work allowed people to work and also visit a place they‚Äôve never been to before. Just an observation and as always I love the content and you have inspired me to change my career trajectory to Data Analytics. Once I get a job I‚Äôll donate 1/4 of my first paycheck to you as a massive thank you for the free content you have provided!

author: @Louisianish
text: Analyzing statistics in a dataset is like slowly peeling back layers of an onion, if you think about it. The more layers of the proverbial onion that you peel back (i.e. the deeper you dive into the data and differentiate between correlation and causation), the closer you get to understanding the key factors that drive certain trends in the industry you are analyzing.

author: @charlesgrace2611
text: Thanks for the video, the top and most of the middle tier industries didn't surprise me too much. I am enrolled in a bootcamp, finishing next Friday. If you have any interest in a Q&A from someone who lived through it I can both validate certain assumptions that exist while also disproving others. There wasn't a lot of information I found on which bootcamp would be worth my time which for me is a big red flag. I can see value in removing the bias curtain a bit to give yourself and others the chance to better understand why they're both good and bad for the DA industry.

author: @sergioramos3437
text: I think a good video would be how to turn a human question into a specific question for your analysis and how break big analysis problems into smaller steps and think computationally...may be a little heady but I think walking through that process with someone who is experienced would be super helpful...  Or a video on how you think about how you decide on a visualization and what to include in it , or how you prepare a presentation... As I've been working with tableau the amount of choices can be overwhelming   Also maybe a mock data analyst interview video lol where it feels like I'm on video call being interviewed so I can practice answering questions

author: @sergioramos3437
text: From my search there are a lot of positions an real estate for analyst.. three job titles I've found and my understanding of them so far  are: "Real estate analyst" (don't know why it's a seperate title) , "Aquisitions analyst" (should we buy this) and "asset management analyst" (how are our properties doing) It's a lot of running the numbers on a property to see if it makes sense as an investment, and on properties already in the company's portfolio to asses how they are performing. It's a lot of financial type stuff, in fact, I'm applying for a "financial analyst" position at a local real estate firm
